results.title: Elephants: their last stand
results.brief_description: This film is about the conflict between people and elephants. In the Samburu district of Kenya, herds of elephants have raided farms, trampled crops and imperilled a struggling people’s way of life. Unfortunately there is no easy solution to the problem of whether to eliminate the elephants or to protect them as part of the country’s unique heritage.

results.title: Elephant theatre (K)
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Sabrina Schmid
results.brief_description: One man has built a little theatre which he can hold in the palm of his hand. It reveals a world of its own. Yet there remains one dream to be fulfilled: that some elephants will come to live in it.

results.title: Elephant parts
results.brief_description: This highly entertaining, Grammy award-winning video by Mike Nesmith, former member of the 60s band, The Monkees (America’s answer to the Beatles) has it all - music, dance, comedy skits, and a cast of thousands! Using satire, nothing in this video is sacred as Nesmith takes a shot at American culture, politics, the Hollywood movie industry and the music industry, game shows, etc etc. Original, clever, witty, “Elephant parts” features several of Nesmith’s songs (all written, produced and sung by Nesmith) including “Rio”, “Cruisin’”, “Magic”, “Tonight” and “Light”. Contains some b&w scenes.

results.title: Elephant boy
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, Alexander Korda, Robert Joseph Flaherty and Zoltan Korda
results.brief_description: Based on Kipling”s “Toomai of the Elephants”, with Sabu as little Toomai, son of the Mahout, and Kala Nag, the elephant. Tells the story of a government expedition in search of wild elephants in the state of Mysore. Toomai’s adventures with Kala Nag and the herd of wild elephants finally leads him to be accorded with the same title of his famous grandfather “Toomai of the Elephants”. This film was beset with difficulties from the start. After years of attempting to obtain sufficient finance to film Kipling’s original story, Flaherty found support from Alexander Korda in 1935 and the Flahertys journeyed to India to adopt (from them) a new method of film making - the original practice adopted by Flaherty of “letting the story flow” and absorbing the way of life of native people and their surroundings was not entirely carried out in the case of “Elephant boy”. Whilst much of the film was shot in studios in England, the film is distinguished by beautiful photography and many fine sequences breathing the very atmosphere of India, captured by Flaherty on location

results.title: Elephant baby
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Milan Herzog
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of a baby elephant from its first day in the jungle, through many weeks of training, to the day it joins a working force of elephants in a lumber camp. Photographed in Mysore, India, the film gives an account of the daily activities of working elephants and of the people who train them, including the shooting of a tiger which came too close to the camp for comfort.

results.title: Elephant (2004) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Blue Relief, Fearmakers Studios, Home Box Office, Dany Wolf and Gus Van Sant
results.brief_description: This austere work from Gus Van Sant, based on the Columbine High School tragedy, presents two days in the life of the young killers and their victims. Following on from the style set in “Gerry” (2002) Van Sant allows long takes and unobtrusive camera work to watch the students in their milieu. Van Sant displays ordinary teenagers beset by loneliness, pettiness, insecurities and rivalry. Cast includes: Alex Frost, Eric Deulen, John Robinson, Elias McConnell and Jordan Taylor. Also available on VHS [319040].

results.title: Elephant
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Peter Chermayeff
results.brief_description: Shows without commentary the African elephant on its daily routine of foraging, dusting, playing, roaming anddrinking from a waterhole. Illustrates the elephants physical characteristics. Suitable for primary school level.
